dialogues.text: I know. It’s like I can’t say anything around them.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: They can just be....a lot. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Thanks for driving me.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: No worries, we’re all in the same sort of area.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Did you have fun, Kayla?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Yeah, totally.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Good. I’m glad. You’re so easy and fun and to be around. Isn’t she? Riley laughs.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Totally.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: That’s what high school’s gonna be like for you, Kayla, just easy, fun, screwing around. It’s all just stupid, you know? Everyone’s as stupid as you. Kayla laughs.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not saying you're stupid, I just mean, you know, everyone's dumb and you just get to be dumb together.  76.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Hahaha, I know what you mean. The car turns.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: You wanna drop her off first?

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: You're right here.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: We should get her back, it’s late.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: It’s fine!

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Yeah, all good.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Okay, cool. The car stops. Olivia gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This was fun!

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Totally!

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Let’s hang out again soon!

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: That'd be awesome!

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Cool. Okay, you’re great, you’re awesome, you’re the best, goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Hahaha night.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Bye Riles.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Byyyye.  Olivia closes the door. The car pulls away. Just Riley and Kayla now. Riley driving. Kayla in the behind him. It’s quiet for a while. RILEY (CONT’D) Olivia's cool, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Totally. She’s the best.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, we’re like best friends.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: That’s awesome.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Kind of awkward talking when you're in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Yeah hahaha.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Here, hold on. 77. seat Riley pulls the car over on the side of the street and st

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Should I get in the front?

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: No, it’s all good. Riley turns off the car. And gets out.  78. Kayla waits, frozen in the back seat. Not quite sure what happening right now. Riley enters the back seat from the passenger side and si beside Kayla. Kayla smiles at him, nervous, then faces ahead. RILEY (CONT’D) So...you excited about next year?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Yeah, totally.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: You should be. You’re like the coolest freshman I’ve met and you’re not even a freshman yet. Kayla laughs, shifts.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: You gotta be careful with guys, though. They’1ll be all over you next year.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: (taken aback, blushing) Wh-...really?

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Oh definitely. They’11 all want you.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Haha yeah right.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: I’m serious. A long silence. Then: RILEY (CONT’D) Truth or Dare?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Truth or Dare? You play Truth or Dare before?  79.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: ...yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Truth or Dare?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Um...... truth.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Okayyy.-....- uhhhh....how far have you gone?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: ..-how far have I gone?

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, like...first base, second base--

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, totally, I know, I was just thinking...trying to remember...like recently or all time?

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: All time.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Hm..... probably....third?

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Whoa.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: You know what actually just second I think, I get confused and mix second and third up sometimes haha.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: ..-You’re funny...It’s okay if you haven't done anything.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Wanna ask me?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Okay...How far have you gone?  80.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: No, Truth or Dare?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Oh Ha ha, yeah, durrr, um, Truth or Dare?

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Dare.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Okay....um.... Kayla looks around, trying to think of something. She ben down, picks up something.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put this quarter in your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Ew!!

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: (panicked) Sorry, you don’t have to, what do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: (pretending to think) Um....I don’t know...I could take off my shirt? Is that stupid?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: (forgetting to breathe) seca no. Riley takes off his shirt. Kayla blushes hard. Tries not look. Heart pounding out of her chest.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Truth or Dare?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: weneee Truth.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Aw you’re no fun.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: ee eee Okay....Dare.... A long silence. The worst.  81.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Take your shirt off.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Um...I'm not really comfortable with that.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Do you think I'm comfortable right now?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Heh-uh...

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Just relaxxx, take a deep breath, it's fine, come on, take your shirt off. He touches her shoulder. She explodes.

dialogues.speaker: NO.
dialogues.text: (then, tiny) Sorry. Riley backs off. Kayla frozen. After a moment. Riley puts his shirt back on. INT. RILEY’S CAR. LATER Riley drives, staring straight ahead. Kayla sits behind h head down. The mood has shifted. A long, tense silence.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: I’m really sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: It’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: wecces I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: IT’S FINE. Kayla shuts up, scared. Riley regains his composure.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s just...look this was about you. I’m trying to help you.  82.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: I know, I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: (angry) Stop saying you’re sorry. I said it was fine so stop saying that, okay?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: I was trying to help you. I-....And now you’re gonna have your first hookup with some asshole at a party next year and you’re not gonna be good at it and he’s gonna tell all his friends about it and you’re gonna get made fun of and feel like shit. Do you want that?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: I didn’t need this. You did. I’m on the other side, already. I hook up all the time. I know what I’m doing.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: I know--

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: But I thought to myself, you know what, this Kayla is a good girl and she needs to be looked out for...so I’m gonna do her a favor. I’m gonna let her hook up with me and I’m gonna let her make mistakes and I’m not gonna judge her if she’s not good at it. I’m just gonna be there for her and I’m gonna give her tips and I’m gonna help her get good at hooking up with guys.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: I know...I really appreciate it. Really. I know you’re just trying to help me. It’s just...I don’t know...I’m sor--...I just didn’t want to do it...It was just a lot all at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riley shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: I tried to help.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: But you don’t want help.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: I do. I really do.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: No you don’t. They drive in silence. Tears well in Kayla’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Please don’t tell your Olivia about this.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: I won't.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Riley’s car pulls up on Kayla’s street corner.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Goodnight. Kayla closes the door and the car drives away. Kayla begins walking down the street, fists and body clenched, breathing through her nose. We get close and fo her as she walks down the dark suburban street back, movi quickly, tense and pained. INT. KAYLA’S HOUSE. LATER. Kayla walks through the front door, moving quickly throug the house towards her room. INT. KAYLA’S ROOM. CONTINOUS. Kayla enters her room, closes the door, and finally lets  84. She collapses onto the floor by her bed, sobbing into her hands. It is loud and heavy. Her body shakes.

dialogues.speaker: DAD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Honey? Dad enters the bedroom and rushes over to Kayla.

dialogues.speaker: DAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kayla, what’s wrong?? What happened? He kneels on the ground beside her - rubs her back. He dr off his knees so that he is sitting on the ground with he holding her while she cries.

dialogues.speaker: DAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus, sweetheart, what happened?...honey, honey, what happened? God, ff-, Kayla. Are you okay? You can tell me...Kayla what’s wrong?...oh sweetheart, it’s fine, it’s okay...it’s okay...I’m here, I’m here, I’m right here, I’m right here, I’m right here. Dad hugs her. She does not hug him back. She has her knee to her chest, her arms wrapped around her knees, her eyes shut tight, trying to collapse herself to a single point.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hey guys, it’s Kayla. Her voice is quiet and unaffected, her usual energy gone. speaks slowly, thinking out loud. INT. KAYLA’S HOUSE - BATHROOM. THE NEXT MORNING Kayla, standing in front of the mirror, covers her face i concealer. Applies eyeliner. Her eyes are puffy from crying all night.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So...I’m making this video to say that I don’t think I’m gonna be making anymore videos for a while, I think. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don’t know if anyone is even watching or cares, but if you are I just want you to know that I’m gonna take a break from videos for a while and I’m sorry if that’s a bummer for you but I think it’s the right thing to do. INT. MILES GROVE MIDDLE SCHOOL - CLASSROOM. LATER. It’s before class has started, kids chat, leaning towards each other in their small desk chairs. Kayla sits in the middle of this, talking to no one. Zoning out.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I started making videos, um, I started making videos so I could give, like, advice and stuff and give you guys tips on what to do to make your lives better or whatever but, um...I don’t know, it’s-... INT. MILES GROVE CAFETERIA. LATER. Kayla sits by herself, eating a sandwich. No list-making. looking around her for kids to potentially approach. She’ quiet as we’ve ever seen her but, for the first time, resigned to be so.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If I’m being really, totally honest, I’m probably not the best person to give advice cause, I don't know, I mean I like giving advice and it’s fun to give advice but...I don’t know...I guess I don’t really know how to do a lot of stuff. I know how to talk about stuff, but I’m not really good at doing stuff. INT. KAYLA’S HOUSE BATHROOM. LATER Kayla sits in a stall on the toilet, browsing her phone, pants on, just wanting some privacy.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: And I'm...I’m really nervous ..-like, all the time, like...for no reason. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like I’1l be nervous even when there’s nothing to be nervous about really. Like...it’s sort of like when you wait in line for a roller coaster and you have that nervous stomach, like I feel like that all the time, like every day, and I don’t ever get that feeling you get after you ride the roller coaster when you feel better. It’s just like I’m waiting in the line all the time. And I try really hard not feel like that but, I don’t know, I just can’t. INT. MILES GROVE MIDDLE SCHOOL HALLWAY. LATER. Kayla walks down the hallway, her backpack on, hands on either strap by her shoulders, her eyes somewhere on the floor in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And so like if you guys are going through tough times, or whatever, you deserve somebody who knows how to get through tough times, you know? Like you deserve someone who’s good at making themselves feel better, cause then maybe they can help you feel better. Kayla turns a corner and continues down the hallway and a from us. On a nearby wall is a bulletin board displaying eighth grade class superlatives.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So yeah, those are, um, some of the reasons I’m gonna take break from videos for a while. Thanks for watching and I hope you all have good lives. I’1l see you around, Maybe. Bye. Among the dozen or so pictures is the one for MOST QUIET. shows a strange boy with his finger to his lips. He is shushing the tiny girl beside him, who is hunched over a book, her face barely visible. INT. KAYLA’S BEDROOM. THAT NIGHT. Kayla lies on her bed, lights on, on her phone. She’s on Instagram, scrolling through her feed.  87. Comments being posted, friends tagging each other in pictures, new relationships budding and breaking, Kayla l but doesn’t participate. KENNEDY GRAVES posted five pictures: SUMMER POOL PARTY!!! Kayla swipes through the mini. Everyone is happy and energetic and having a blast. She can’t find herself in a of the photos. She arrives at the group picture at the diving board. She not in it. Kayla stares at the photo and then closes her eyes. BLOOP. An Instagram chat from Gabe. From Gabe: did you see the photos Kennedy posted? Kayla responds: no. Gabe: there stupid. she didn’t post any of my handstand p Kayla: that sucks Gabe: it’s fine. how are you? Kayla: i actually have to go. Lots of homework. Sorry. Kayla turns off her phone, rolls over onto her side and f the wall. INT. KAYLA’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM. NIGHT Dad is on the couch, browsing his Kindle with reading gla on. Kayla walks in behind him.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Will you help me burn something in the backyard?

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: weeee Yep. EXT. KAYLA’S BACKYARD. LATER. Kayla and Dad are sitting next to each other on plastic l chairs around a small fire burning in the patio’s fire-pi Kayla looks down at the TIME CAPSULE in her lap. Its writing glows by the light of the fire: TO THE COOLES GIRL IN THE WORLD.  88.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: You sure you want to do this?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: I’m not exactly sure what “this” is...or means...I’m just hoping that whatever we’re doing here is a positive thing...?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Alright then. Kayla places the box in the fire pit. It starts to burn. Kayla and Dad watch it.

dialogues.speaker: DAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What was in there?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Nothing, really. Just...sort of my hopes and dreams.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: wees Right.....and you’re burning them?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Alright. Dad puts his arm around his daughter and watches the fire with her. As always, he’s searching for something - anyth to say or do to make his daughter happier. And just as he’s about to say something, just as he’s abo to make another admirable and kind and probably slightly the-mark attempt at helping the little girl that he loves very very much, more than anything, she speaks:

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Do I make you sad?  89.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Wh-..... Sweetheart, no. No. Not at all. Kayla - not at all. Do I seem sad?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Then why would you think you make me sad?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: I don’t know...Sometimes I think that, like, when I grow up, maybe I’ll have a daughter. And then, like, I was thinking, if she was like me, I think that would make me really sad all the time. Cause I would love her a lot because she’s my daughter but...I don’t know, I guess if she ended up being like me, I think being her mom would make me really sad. Kayla stares down at her lap, picks at her nails. Dad pauses, devastated, and then leans in, purposefully, sternly, and says what may be the only thing that he is absolutely, one hundred thousand percent certain of.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: You're wrong. Kayla...Kayla, look at me: (she does) You're wrong...If you grow up to have a daughter like you, she will make you so, so happy. Being your dad makes me so happy, Kayla. You don’t know. You don’t know how happy you make me. It’s beyond anything. I can’t describe it to you. And it’s not just because you're my daughter. It’s not because I’m your dad and I would love you no matter what. It’s because of you. Do you understand? A lot of parents, Kayla, a lot of parents have to love their kids in spite of who they are. Not me. I get to love you because of who you are. Do you get that? Kayla, you are so good. You’re such a good person. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not just saying this, Kayla. It’s true. Kayla, look at me. Look at me: It’s so easy to love you. It’s so easy to be proud of you. I really mean that. And yeah, sometimes when I see you’re upset or having a rough day, it makes me sad. But that being sad, that sort of day-to-day sad stuff or worrying that I do is, it’s -- Kayla, I am always, beneath all that stuff, always just so unbelievably happy that I get to be your dad. (a pause, a deep breath, a decision) ...Kayla, when your mom left, I was really scared. Like really, really scared. Because now I was all alone with this little girl that I loved so much and wanted everything for and I wasn’t sure if I could give you what you needed so I was really scared. I was scared that you weren’t going to be okay. I was scared just like you are right now. More scared. Way more...But then you got older. And you took your first steps, and you said your first words, and you wrote your first letter to Nana and you made your first friend; and everything that I thought I was going to have to teach you - how to be nice, how to share, how to care about other people’s feelings - you just started doing on your own. Your teachers would say, “you’ve got such a lovely daughter, you’ve done such a great job with her.” But I didn’t do anything. I really didn’t. I just watched. And the more I watched you, the less scared I got. I stopped being scared a long time ago, Kayla. You know why? Because of you. You made me brave, Kayla. And if you could just see yourself like I see you...the way you really are, the way you always have been...I promise you wouldn't be scared either. Kayla scoots out of her chair and onto her dad’s lap. She hugs him tight, hugs him in a way that she hasn’t in a ve long time. He hugs her back.  91. The fire burns. The hug does not break. EXT. GABE’S HOUSE. NIGHT Kayla is at the back door of a small house. She goes to knock, stops. Turns and walks away. Stops. Turns back to house. Walks back to the front door. Stops. Takes a deep breath and knocks. Gabe answers the door, dressed in khaki pants and a shirt tie - his hair gelled in a neat part. He is nervous.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Hi Kayla.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Hi Gabe.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: You look really nice.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Thank you. You too.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Thanks. You want to watch a movie later?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Cool. A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on in. Kayla steps inside. INT. GABE’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS Gabe’s house is small and messy. Kayla stands stiffly as closes the door, turns to Kayla, and does a slow bow at t waist, hands at his side.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Welcome.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Thank you.  92.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: How are you tonight?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Good, you?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I’m good and you?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Cool...May I take your coat?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Sure. Gabe helps Kayla out of her hoodie like a gentleman. Then holds the hoodie awkwardly, not sure what to do next.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can hold it.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Okay. Gabe hands her hoodie to her.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you hungry?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Cool. Gabe starts walking, Kayla follows. Gabe leads her into t kitchen where he has set up a romantic DIY dinner for two the table -- two lit candles, two glasses of soda and two plates full of chicken tenders and fries. Everything has been set up very neatly and carefully.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Do you like chicken tenders?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Yeah.  93.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Cool. I got a twenty piece and I also got two of every kind of sauce - but if you have a favorite sauce and want more than one packet of it, you can have mine. I like all the sauces equally.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Thanks. Kayla walks toward one of the chairs. Gabe pulls it out f her and she sits.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: The chicken tenders have been sitting out for a little bit because I didn’t know when you’d be here so tell me if they’re too cold and I can heat them up in the microwave.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Whoops, left this out by accident. Gabe picks up a PIECE OF PAPER that was sitting right bes Kayla’s plate. He stands in front of her, holding it.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean to leave this out. Sorry. So stupid.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: No problem. Gabe doesn’t move. Holds the paper out to Kayla.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: You wanna see it? It’s stupid.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Sure. She grabs it and looks at it. It’s a cheap, print-out awa with Gabe’s name on it.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: It’s stupid.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I go to archery camp every summer and last summer I got five bull’s eyes in a day so they gave me the Sharpshooter of the Week Award.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Wow. That’s really cool.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: It’s stupid. Gabe takes the paper and places it on top of a nearby bur He then walks over to the opposite side of the table, sto poses, shoots an imaginary arrow and then takes his seat opposite Kayla. He grabs his glass of soda and holds it up.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To our first friend hang out! Kayla smiles and lifts her glass. They toast and drink. G digs in to the tenders. Kayla eats cautiously, careful no mess up her lip gloss.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: No problem. Kayla eats a single fry in three bites.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I like your house.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Thanks. It’s my mom's.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: What movie do you want to watch?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: What ones do you have?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I have Netflix so we can watch anything. What kind of movies do you like? What genre?  95.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Um...I don’t know. What do you like?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Lots of stuff. I can watch scary movies without being scared.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: The tenders are a little cold.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: They're fine.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Okay, good. I actually kind of think they're better when they’re cold.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Cool. They eat in silence for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you believe in God?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Um....yes.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Cool. More eating.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Know any good jokes?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Jokes? Um...

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I know a few. Okay, so you know how bikes have two tires? Like on the wheels?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Yeah, totally.  96.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Okay, so why couldn’t the bicycle stand up?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Because it was two tired. Kayla laughs a little out her nose, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: That’s a good one.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I made it up.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Wow, that’s really funny.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Do you have any?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Um..... what did the fish say, hold on...what did the fish say when he swam into the concrete wall--

dialogues.speaker: GABE KAYLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Damn. Damn.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve heard that one, that’s a good one, I like that one.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: You have a good sense of humor and that's what I like so it's good that you have that.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: You’re welcome. Gabe stares at his food, looking agitated. Then:

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have to tell you something.  97.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: (little freaked out) What?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I didn’t make up that bike joke. My dad told it to me.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Oh that’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t have lied to you I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: It's fine. I also sort of think you made the joke you’re own in the way you said it so it’s sort of like you wrote it anyway. Gabe smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Totally. They eat some more in silence.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I watched some of your videos.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Oh...those are stupid.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: No! No, they’re really cool. You’re really smart about stuff. You know so many things.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I was thinking you should have your own talk show.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Hahaha yeah...

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry if I’m being weird, I’m just really nervous.  98.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Your not being weird.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: We’re having a good conversation I think.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Yeah me too. Gabe smiles. Kayla smiles back. INT. GABE’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM. LATER Gabe and Kayla sit on the couch “together” (three feet ap stiff, both facing forward, nervous).

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: ...what do you wanna do?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Oh...whatever.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too, I can do whatever.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: ...you wanna watch something?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Sure. Gabe grabs the remote off the coffee table in front of th He hesitates, puts the remote back down.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Actually...can I show you something?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Okay. Gabe hops up from the couch and runs out of the room. Kay stays put, sitting up straight, knees bouncing, nervous. We stay on Kayla as we hear the sounds of Gabe’s frantic search: loud footsteps down a hallway, a door opens, clos a pause, door opens again, more footsteps.  99.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (just outside the room) Okay, I’m ready to show you.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: It’s not that cool. But maybe you'll think it’s really cool, I don't know, it’s kind of cool, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Close your eyes. Kayla does. We stay on her as Gabe enters the room. Lots little, strange sounds.

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Keep your eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Okay, you can open your eyes. Kayla does. Gabe is standing in front of her with his han behind his back. There’s a large cardboard box behind him a laptop now open on the coffee table between Kayla and h

dialogues.speaker: GABE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, like, I told you about how I do archery and, um, like, this is sort of like another one of my passions. Gabe keeps one hand behind his back as the other reaches and hits the laptop’s spacebar. HEAVY METAL MUSIC begins blast as Gabe pulls TWO LARGE SILVER RINGS from behind hi back and begins his magic routine. Gabe’s hands shake with adrenaline as he does his linking rings routine. Then reaches into the box, does more trick color changing scarves, cutting and melding ropes. The face-melting guitar doesn’t quite match up with Gabe’ routine. But Gabe is taking this very seriously, too nerv to look up at Kayla and see if she’s liking it or not. He practiced this a thousand times, and this is it: his mome  100. And as Gabe struggles through his act, messing up here, dropping a prop there, Kayla watches him. Someone is doing something for her. And she is watching it. Smiling. Her world upside-down. The pressure, finally, for a moment, off. EXT. STREET. GABE’S HOUSE LATER Dad waits in his car, parked on the street in front of Ga house. He stares ahead, turns, sees something, smiles. Kayla enters the car.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Hey. Dad pulls away and starts driving. We stay on the two of them, sitting quietly. A long silence between them, then:

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Did you have fun?

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah it was fun.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Good. They drive. Both staring forward. Sitting in silence. Together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move slowly through the lobby. The floor somehow both scuffed and shiny. A giant trophy case with way too much it. A high ceiling. And empty.  101.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL MCDANIEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Friends, Family, and Loved Ones. The strange sounds of a speech happening in a large, near space. Loud and echoing and muffled through the walls. Ba discernible. We continue to move slowly through the lobby and toward a open hallway entrance.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL MCDANIEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Today is a celebration. A chance for us to applaud the achievements of these amazing kids. Miles Grove Middle School’s Class of 2017. Applause. Even louder. Even stranger sounding. Principal Mcdaniel’s speech fades to barely audible as we move down hallway. It’s dark. Something in the distance. We keep moving. Get closer. Kids waiting in the dark, lined up against the right wall the hallway in single file. Dressed in caps and gowns. A CHAPERONE (40s) at the front of the line by the entranc the Gym. The kids are chatting, bored, not really caring about whatever they’re supposed to be caring about right

dialogues.speaker: CHAPERONE
dialogues.text: (whisper yelling) Guys! Guys! We’re almost there, a few more minutes, please, please just, guys! Shhhh, just shhhh please and thank you. We pass the Chaperone and continue down the line. Boy, gi boy, girl, girl, girl, boy, boy, boy, girl, b--wait. Kayla. Cap too big for her head. Swimming in her gown. She stand straight, hands clenched into fists at her side. She look down the hall, sees something. Aiden. He’s late, hustling toward the back of the line. Looking cute even in that stupid robe. Kayla watches him as he passes. Then faces forward. Stare Then makes a decision.  102. She steps out of her place and begins walking quickly dow the line. We follow her. She moves with confidence and purpose. Aiden’s ahead, fixing his cap over his stupid he Kayla reaches him. And passes. Keeps walking. She finally stops and turns. Kennedy Graves is standing with Steph and another friend. on their phones.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Hey. Kennedy looks up. Too confused to even react. Kayla speaks the following in what seems like one breath.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wrote you that letter thanking you for having me to your party and you didn’t write back, like not even a facebook message, and that’s really stupid and mean. And being mean isn’t cool, it’s MEAN. When someone does something nice you're supposed to do something nice back. I’m always nice to you and you’re never nice to me and that’s not fair. I’m a good person and you should be nicer to me. Kennedy looks shocked/disgusted. Kayla turns to walk away whips back.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (angrier) And that card game I got you for your birthday is actually REALLY FUN and you’d know that if you actually PLAYED IT. And I know you probably think it’s stupid but stupid games can be fun sometimes, like if it’s raining outside or whatever, it’s a great game, it’s like a really fun version of Go Fish, and if you actually just tried playing it instead of trying to be cool all the time you'd realize that it’s really fun game to play when you’re bored. And- Kayla turns and walks away. Back up the line. The adrenal of the moment still coursing through her. She retakes her spot in line. Taking deep breaths to calm herself.  103. She smiles. The familiar sounds of PHOTOBOOTH. BEEP BEEP BEEP CLICK:

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hey Kayla, it’s me, Kayla. The line starts to move. Kayla walks with her classmates, the line funnels from the dark hallway through the bright door to the gymnasium.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Congrats on finishing high school! I’m so, so, so, so, SO proud of you. INT. KAYLA’S BEDROOM. LATER THAT DAY Kayla is sitting at her desk, still in her graduation rob speaking to her laptop’s webcam.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: It’s crazy to think that you’re almost 18. You probably look a lot different than me, which is cool, but also if you still sort of look like this that’s cool too. INT. KAYLA’S BEDROOM. LATER. CLOSE ON a USB DRIVE KOALA BEAR, plugged into Kayla’s lap Kayla pulls it out. We continue to hear Kayla’s video.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: How did you do on the SATs? Did you suck at the math part? It’s okay if you did. Math is stupid. Kayla places the Koala Bear into a BRAND NEW SHOEBOX full tiny trinkets and keepsakes: a picture of Kayla and her d a bracelet, Aiden’s crazy straw, the strip of pictures wi Olivia from the mall photobooth , a sauce packet from Gab

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Do you have a boyfriend? If you don't that’s fine! And if you do, I hope he is treating you well. You deserve it. Kayla puts the lid on the shoebox. On the lid, in freshly colored marker, are the words: TO THE COOLEST GIRL IN THE WORLD.  104. EXT. KAYLA’S BACKYARD. DAY. Kayla places her new time capsule into a two-foot deep, crudely-dug hole in her backyard - a pile of loose dirt beside it. Dad watches her, smiling, holding a shovel. He begins shoveling the loose dirt back into the hole.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Is dad still a dork? If he’s not still a dork, he’s probably an alien just wearing dad’s skin as a disguise and you should kill him right after you read this. The brightly-colored shoebox disappears more and more wit every shovelful of dirt. INT. KAYLA’S BATHROOM. NIGHT. Kayla stands in front of the mirror. Dressed for somethin Hair and makeup done up.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I hope you’re not too sad about leaving all your friends for college. Kayla lifts up her phone, poses for a selfie. INT. DAD'S CAR. LATER THAT NIGHT. Kayla rides shotgun. Dad drives. They are talking about something, making small talk, laughing, happy.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But if you are sad, just remember that can still stay in touch with all of your high school friends and you'll make tons of new friends at your new school next year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The END OF THE YEAR DANCE is bumping. Sweaty pubescent ki grind and “dance” with each other. Kayla walks in, lookin beautiful as always.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And I know you probably don’t want advice from an eighth grader...  105. Kayla walks into the middle of the large mob of her peers She starts to dance.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .--but I just want you to know that if high school sucked for you, I'm really sorry and that sucked but...it's whatever, I mean, middle school sucked for me but I'm past it now and I'm moving forward. And you can do that with high school too. She dances harder. Arms, hips, shoulders, head. All movin

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Just cause things are happening to you right now, doesn't mean that things are always going to happen to you. You never know what's going to happen next and that's what makes things exciting and scary...and fun... She is dancing her heart out. No one is paying attention. doesn’t notice. She doesn’t care. Eyes closed. Hips and a and hair wildly in motion.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So yeah, stay cool and I can't wait to be you....Love, Kayla.
